# Bitcoin solves the problem that money presents. To think of BTC in terms of exchange value is to misunderstand the problem.
Disagree. These were incremental changes in the context of # Bitcoin.
Creating more billionaires with # Bitcoin doesn’t change anything. Changing how humans think about money for the first time ever - thanks to exponential hashrate growth - changes everything.
To think about # Bitcoin in units of ‘Lambos’ (exchange value) is to miss the point of what makes this revolution interesting. We haven’t had a change in how humans think about money like this ever.

Hashrate growth gives BTC value above ‘exchange value.’ Hashrate growth is how you get to a $100,000+ price target. Hashrate growth is how you replace a legacy fiat system with Bitcoin. Bitcoin is a tech coup driven by exponential hash growth.

7/ This is rent seeking at its purest. What's worse is that there's a conflation between these tokens an BTC. Centralized money and Decentralized sound money. They shouldn't be conflated. They're really, really different yet are placed in the same general category: cryptocurrency

4/ Instead, what's happened is that there are still lots of people that want to be "money creators" without the expense of mining. What do they do? They create altcoins, ICOs or token sales. They want to become the centralized version of Bitcoin. They aim to be sound money.

3/ In bitcoin, you have the same dynamics as gold. It's very expensive to get into Bitcoin mining. You would think this would lead to a lot more people trying to provide goods and services people want.

The people that wanted to make *Bitcoin* better and not trying to sell tokens of one type or another have stayed. What I've noticed is that the good devs are the ones trying to make Bitcoin better. The bad ones generally try to sell more or less useless stuff.

There has always been people that have been coding to make Bitcoin better. There have always been people trying to "get rich" by creating their own token starting way back with altcoins in 2011. The latter group moved to ETH because it was a better platform for them.

Third, the Coinbase API is hardly the bastion of developer activity. Real development was going on in wallets, alternate implementations and of course Bitcoin core. The people in those things, did they move to ETH? Perhaps, but I don't recall many.

Second, Vitalik wasn't as much a dev as he was a writer. He wrote lots for Bitcoin Magazine, for example. Yes, he wrote a Python Bitcoin Library, but have you looked at the code? It's almost like it's written by an amateur 19-year-old with zero software development experience!

Voting isn't a part of Bitcoin's consensus process. Some have misinterpreted Satoshi's "1-CPU-1-vote" statement as if it applies regardless of the rules being enforced by individual users. If you wish to be subject to the whims of a few powerful entities, use a different network.

"Blockchain" can be traced to 1991 when Stuart Haber and W. Scott Stornetta described the first work on a cryptographically secured chain of blocks. In 1992, they incorporated Merkle trees into the design allowing several documents to be collected into a block.
